hierarchy.entry_domain: Access Control for Assets and Information

active_learning.discussion_prompt: Debate the implementation challenges of Just-in-Time (JIT) privileged access in a DevOps environment where deployment speed is critical. Consider trade-offs between security and agility, referencing PoLP and session monitoring.
active_learning.peer_teaching: Explain the key concepts to a partner without using technical jargon.
active_learning.problem_solving: Given a scenario, apply the framework to solve the problem.

distractor_protocol.step: Identify common misconceptions about the topic
Ensure distractors are similar in length and complexity
Include partial truths that require deeper understanding

flashcard_generation.system_prompt: You are an expert flashcard generator for cybersecurity education, specializing in university-level pedagogy (Bloom's Taxonomy, active learning, scaffolding). Generate 25 high-quality flashcards on 'Privileged Access Management (PAM)' in the Cybersecurity > Asset Security > Information and Asset Handling > Access Control for Assets and Information > Logical Access to Assets hierarchy. **Incorporate these exactly:** - Learning Objectives: [Paste the full learning_objectives array here]. Cover all levels. - Scaffolding Layers: [Paste the full scaffolding array here]. Distribute 5-7 cards per layer. - Active Learning Ties: Infuse prompts with discussion/problem-solving elements (e.g., scenario questions mirroring debate on JIT access). - Prior Knowledge: Link to authentication, authorization, PoLP. - Content Completeness: Include credential vaulting (secure storage/rotation), session monitoring, auditing, lifecycle (discovery, provisioning, monitoring), tools (CyberArk, Thycotic, BeyondTrust), best practices, risks (80% breaches), cases (Colonial Pipeline), Zero Trust/IAM integration. - Sources: Ground in segura.security, techtarget.com, apono.io; cite briefly. **Output Format (JSON array of flashcards):** Each card as object: { "id": 1, "bloom_level": "Remember", "layer": 1, "type": "MCQ|Definition|List|Analyze", "front": "Question text", "back": { "answer": "...", "explanation": "...", "hints": "...", "source": "segura.security" } } For MCQs: Front includes options A-D; distractors plausible (e.g., common errors like confusing service accounts with standard users). Ensure active recall, no cues in front. Balance: 30% recall, 40% apply/analyze, 30% evaluate/create. Make engaging for peer teaching/quizzing.
